conclusion: Figure 1 shows the waveform of the transverse harmonic wave at t = 2s, plotted against the x-axis (position). Figure 2 shows the vibration of the particle at x = 2m, plotted against time t.
In Figure 1, the waveform at t = 2s shows a peak at x = 1m and a trough at x = 4m.
In Figure 2, the particle at x = 2m starts at y = 0 at t = 0, moves upward to a positive peak at t = 1s, and then downward to a negative peak at t = 3s.
The wave is propagating to the right along the x-axis because the waveform shifts in the positive x-direction as time progresses.
The amplitude (A) is given as A = 10cm.
The period (T) is determined to be T = 4s from Figure 2, as the time for one complete oscillation is from t = 0 to t = 4s.
The wavelength (λ) is determined to be λ = 4m from Figure 1, as the distance between two consecutive peaks is from x = 1m to x = 5m.
The wave speed (v) is calculated using the formula v = λ / T, resulting in v = 4m / 4s = 1m/s.
The direction of wave propagation is to the right, and the wave speed is 1m/s.
